Rebased onto recent changes merging single- and multi-output ParDo evaluator factories. SplittableParDo now overrides only the multi-output ParDo (because single-output is overridden into multi-output).

However, I had to restore TransformHooks in ParDoEvaluatorFactory, because splittable and non-splittable are treated differently. But at least I could remove one type argument (POutput type - which is now always PCollectionTuple).
Reopened pull request to rerun tests.

R: -@kennknowles

(since @tgroh is on it quite well)

@kennknowles , thank your the review and sorry for the lack of context. 

The test in the PR title is flaky. The reason is one of the transforms result in at least one empty bundle. And depending on the thread scheduling, sometimes this empty bundle arrives as the last bundle to the native write transform.

DirectPipelineRunner implements native write transform by accumulating all data carrying bundles and then writing them as a single shard. Empty bundles arriving after the write happened was not handled before and it was resulting in overwriting the output files with empty data.

Please take another look.

Added some comments at the top of the files, although in many cases they're similar to the descriptions. As these will be changing soon, I think this is enough for now, and they'll be expanded when we update the test suites.

PTAL: @davorbonaci @kennknowles

I've moved changes to other runners to other PRs and got Jenkins green ([here](https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_MavenVerify/5151/), but one more fixup coming and since there was a massive rebase I'm just going to squash it).

The unusual class cast errors that we discussed were due to compiler-inserted casts failing. I found and eliminated the rawtypes that let the type errors through.
@kennknowles do you have any comments?
PTAL @davorbonaci
R: @kennknowles @dhalperi

There's just BEAM-25, but I just filed [BEAM-1035](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1035)

Thanks! I also filed [BEAM-1036](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1036) to track it. I think the only two things that need to happen are (1) clean up state so you don't leak and (2) make sure to GBK appropriately. The rest is handled by generic support code.
Filed [BEAM-1037](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1037) for `ApexRunner` based on @amitsela's comments on #1409.
Filed [BEAM-1038](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1038) against myself following @amitsela's comments on #1409.
Thanks!

R: @tgroh
@kennknowles I just found the build failure and it is due to changes in Apex. We are waiting for the 3.5.0 release to update the dependency of he Apex runner.
Please hold on with merging the PR until the snapshot is updated.

I think one of the reasons we didn't do this was concern about the potential memory impact -- doing a window at a time means we don't need all the state for all the windows to fit in memory at once. Have we measured that (1) this necessary and (2) this isn't going to cause additional memory pressure?

Thanks @tenghuanhe, your contribution is much appreciated.

On a high level, it seems to me that the fix is specific to the local file system, and may not work if the temporary directory is located remotely, e.g., in HDFS, Google Cloud Storage, or S3. On the other hand, `FileBasedSink` is intended to work on all these systems.

As a general approach, perhaps the fix could live in the specific implementation of the `IOChannelFactory` for the local file system.

What do you think?

Also, CC: @peihe, who is a subject matter expert, and could perhaps provide more specific guidance.

I have observed up to a 15% improvement in a nexmark benchmark where we
receive bundles of 10 timers at a time etc and without this we end up doing
10 serial get data requests for the key.
I think that memory impact is bounded since only prefetch up to 1MB from
each tag list and paginate the rest upon demand and thus doesn't seem like
to large a concern (or at least not any more than many timers firing for
many different keys at the same time).

Can you merge `apache:master` into `apache:gearpump-runner` and then rebase `manuzhang:gearpump-runner`, to clear out the excess commits?
OK, I will wait. Can you just remove the tags and add the dependencies?

This setup is to ensure that the transitive dependencies are used as declared by Apex (vs. repeating them). The real issue is that we depend on the snapshot, and that's the result of the issue identified in the jenkins environment as part of #540
Ugh. Wrong PR. Sorry.
